comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: On December 15, 1913, Diry, a middleweight, was knocked out by George Ashe in the third round of a contest at the National Sporting Club, in Brooklyn, New York. Diry was from Ireland, where his name was spelled (and pronounced) "Deery." He had won a fight in November, but this was his second loss since then, and he endured three more knockouts early in 1914, before hanging up his gloves for good. Diry's boxing record: boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=73885&cat=boxer New York Times story, December 16, 1913: (The Times calls him a German, and says that he had won several fights, but the record contradicts that statement.) query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9807E...

comment.author: 8560391@N03
comment._content: Hi Wystan. I tend to believe the Diry was indeed German, not Irish, as another NYT link credits him as the German middleweight champion (see his boxrec.com bio). The only source I'm finding that says he's Irish is the info at the top of his boxrec.com record, but I believe that's an error, and I'm also going to guess that whoever compiled his "official" record there got most if not all of the results from the same NYT links we're seeing.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: There were also many boxers who were not Irish but fought under Irish names in that era.
